thread.title: Fourth employer says cash given to CFMEU to work in Canberra
thread.title_full: Fourth employer says cash given to CFMEU to work in Canberra | afr.com

author: Ewin Hannan
title: Fourth employer says cash given to CFMEU to work in Canberra
text:
A fourth employer told the trade union royal commission on Tuesday that he made allegedly corrupt payments to a former CFMEU organiser. by Ewin Hannan A fourth Canberra employer allegedly made corrupt payments to a former construction union organiser to get work on building projects in the ACT.
Plasterer Jian Yu He told the trade union royal commission on Tuesday that he paid $5000 in cash to Halafihi "Fihi" Kivalu, who until 2014 was an organiser with the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union.
Mr He, giving evidence through an interpreter, said Mr Kivalu initially demanded $10,000 but Mr He "negotiated it down" to $5000.
"He said without paying it's possible that I cannot stay in Canberra for work," he told the commission.
Mr He said he handed over $2000 and $3000 in cash while sitting in Mr Kivalu's car on two different days.
"Fihi said to me, 'If this money, is not paid, this will cause trouble'," Mr He said.
On another occasion about a year earlier, Mr He said his former partners agreed to pay $10,000 to Mr Kivalu to work on another job. He said $2000 towards the payment was handed over during dinner at a Canberra restaurant.
On Monday, Canberra contractor Elias Taleb told the commission that he made the payments totalling more than $135,000 to Mr Kivalu throughout 2012 and 2013.
 Four payments ​Tiling contractor Medwhat Eleaswiy told the hearing he made four payments to Mr Kivalu, including one for $10,000. Another employer, Tony Bassil, said he made payments totalling thousands of dollars to Mr Kivalu.
Mr Kivalu was sacked by the union in 2014 but the CFMEU said his position was made redundant and his dismissal was unrelated to the allegations. Dave Noonan, the CFMEU's construction division national secretary, said the allegations of "bribery" were serious and should be referred to police.
Mr He said on Tuesday that a CFMEU representative, who he knew only as "Johnny", approached him in June to ask him to pay for 10 union memberships.
He said he paid "a bit more than $2000" to the union for six employees. "He (Johnny) said he wants me to put 10 members into the union [and] if this isn't done the boss will not be happy," Mr He said.
The practice of employers paying for union memberships has attracted controversy, after the commission heard evidence it occurred in the Australian Workers Union when Labor leader Bill Shorten led the union.
​Builder Robert Rae told the commission that he was asked by Mr Eleaswiy to meet Mr Kivalu and give him cheques.
End any problems "[Mr Eleaswiy] said it was for the good of the company to win work and it was to end any problems on the job," he said.
Mr Rae said he met Mr Kivalu at a McDonald's restaurant in Canberra and Mr Kivalu was angry that the payment was not made in cash.
"When I gave him the cheque he was rather upset about it. He expected cash," he said.
Ivan Bulum, who has worked in the construction industry since 1967, told the commission subcontractors had told him that they had made cash payments to the union.
Mr Bulum said three men – a bricklayer, a formworker and a concreter – told him separately that the CFMEU had asked them for money but he had no direct evidence of any payments.
Mr Kivalu is yet to give evidence before the commission, which will spend another two weeks examining the conduct of the CFMEU in the ACT.
Counsel assisting the commission Jeremy Stoljar has said the evidence would "paint a disturbing picture of the conduct of the CFMEU in the ACT: alleged corrupt payments, standover and intimidation tactics, and the apparent establishment and promotion of cartels for key trades".
